• Layouts

    Introduction

    We leverage CSS to lay elements out on the page. However, there is a distinction between layouts dictating the major and minor components of a page. The minor are called Modulesand include Accordions, Modals, and Tabs; while the major Componentsinclude the headerand footer.

    Naming Conventions

    • All style naming conventions use classes and not ID selectors.
    • All class names are lowercase and hyphenated.
    • Layout class names begin with a l-.

    Layout class names begin with a l-row l-full-width-coll-row l-two-col-left-narrowl-row l-two-col-left"l-row l-two-col-right-widel-row l-two-col-evenl-row l-two-col-left-widel-row l-two-col-rightl-row l-two-col-right-narrowl-three-coll-row l-three-col-evenl-row l-four-col-evenl-row l-five-col-evenl-row l-six-col-even.

    Examples

    Bad CSS structure might look something like this:

    <!-- examples of bad naming conventions -->
<div id="Row"></div>
    <div class="Row_Header"></div>
<div class="row"></div>

    Good CSS structure might look something like this:

    <!-- examples of bad naming conventions -->
<div class="l-row"></div>
    <div class="l-row l-header">
</div>

    The Structure

    Layouts are brokendown into two parts, Rows and Columns.

    All content should live within a row in order for it to responsively adapt to the 15px16px16px12px 12px page wrapper.

    There's only two types of row class names, l-row and l-row header. The difference it that the default row adds a 22px space on the left and sometimes has a 22px space on the right (based on the type of content). As a developer or content editor, always use the l-row as the other is reserved for special applications.

    Good CSS structure might look something like this:

    <!-- default row -->
<div class="l-row"></div>

    Top

  • Columns

    Layouts are brokendown into two parts, Rows and Columns.

    All content (modules) should live within a column nested in a row in order for it react responsively.

    There's are many types of column class names to include: l-col, l-full-width-col, l-col, l-col, l-col, l-col, l-col, l-col, and l-col. By combining them in logical sequences, the modules will move, adapt, expand, contract to the users' page resolution on their media device. Columns can be nested as well but the examples below are all of the column layouts that fir the needs of the EIA website.

    Top

  • Single Columns

    Full-Width Column


    l-row l-full-width-col

    The fullpage row is similar to the class="l-row l-header but can be applied to the entire section. An example might include a 'dashboard' page with multiple rows and columns.

    • 15px
    • 12px
    • 12px
    • 12px
    • 12px
    • 22px
    • px or 100%100%100%100%100% 100%
    • 22px
    • 12px
    • 12px
    • 12px
    • 12px
    • 15px
